newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Relatives wail after 24 die in Bangladesh stampede.
newsitem.headline: Relatives wail after 24 die in Bangladesh stampede.

text.p: Police on Thursday struggled to disperse hundreds of angry protesters trying to storm a locked up building in the Bangladesh capital where a fatal stampede killed at least 24 garment workers and injured over 100, witnesses said.
Outside the morgue at the Dhaka Medical College Hospital, grieving parents and relatives wailed inconsolably as they waited for the bodies of the victims.
"Let me take my daughter home," said a 50-year-old man. His daughter Yasim (one name) was among the dead.
The stampede occurred on Wednesday evening after an electrical short circuit at Shanghai Apparels, one of four garment factories housed in the multi-storey building at Dhaka's Mirpur area.
"Although there had not been any actual fire, it (the short circuit) caused a severe panic among workers of the Shanghai Apparels and in the three other factories," one police officer said.
"Some 1,000 workers at the factories started scrambling down narrow stairs causing severe suffocation and many also jumped from fourth floor windows," one fire brigade officer said.
Most of the victims were women, who constitute 90 percent of textile workers in Bangladesh.
Police said the workers panicked because eight people had been killed in another garment factory fire in the capital on July 16.
Demonstrators at Mirpur shouted slogans against the factory owners, some accusing them of ignoring safety requirements.
Police and military officials at the scene said they were expecting President Shahabuddin Ahmed to visit the factories.
As survivors gave horrific accounts of the accident, the authorities on Thursday announced a decision to give compensation to families of the victims.
Each family will receive 100,000 taka ($2,272), half of it provided by the government and half by the Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association (BGMEA).

"I feel I escaped from hell. Hundreds were shouting fire, fire. I ran to the staircase on the fourth floor but couldn't get down as dozens of others were climbing up for safety," said Dolly Begum, 20, looking bewildered.
"I then took off my saree, tied it to a window grille and managed to climb down to the street," she told reporters at Mirpur.
"Many others did the same and scores jumped out of the windows. The air was heavy with people screaming, shouting and crying for help," Begum said.
Police said the factory's owners and managers stayed away in fear of attacks by outraged workers and relatives of the victims.
A senior fire brigade official said most of the garment factories in Dhaka lacked fire escapes and held no fire-fighting exercises.
Some 150 workers have been killed and at least 500 injured in a series of garment factory fires in recent years, he said without giving details.
BGMEA President Golam Quddus said the association had served notice last week on all garment factories to ensure the required fire-prevention measures were taken.
"We have told them to immediately arrange a second staircase at every factory and mobilise adequate fire fighting materials," he told Reuters on Thursday.
"I admit many factories have ignored the matter in the past. Now we have asked them to correct their mistakes or face cancellation of the association's membership."
